dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN ON MARTIN HART staring directly at us, seated at a TABLE. He’s 56, tall, broad. He has thick gray hair, clos cropped, a hard face. He wears a well-made suit, and ther a kind of physical intensity in his bearing. He simmers-- Cigarette burns and gouges pock the table’s linoleum surf and behind Hart is only a green plaster WALL, empty excep for its upper right side, in which half a BULLETIN BOARD in frame, and on it, half of a WANTED POSTER can be seen- As Martin stares at us, WORDS are typed into the bottom o the screen, courier typeface, to the SOUND of keys punchi CHYRON: ‘Arkansas State Police CID, Company D / Statement Hart, Martin Eric. / Present: Sgt. Thomas F. Papania, Sgt Maynard Gilbough / May, 2010’

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (into camera) What’d I think? ...You know they called him ‘The Banker’ for a while?.. Department opened up some new positions in CID that year. Cocaine was on the rise, and meth was getting big. So I partnered up. A beat, then he seems to speak as if in response to a question-- HART (CONT’D) Seemed a little raw-boned to me. A little edgy. Finally get him over for dinner, around the time of our first female 419- the ‘Pine Angel’ in Benton County... That’s what you all really want to talk about, right? Dora Lange? Another beat as he seems to listen--  HART (CONT’D) Alright. Rust- Well, as a ‘for instance,’ I finally got him over for dinner. The case was still hot, and I had a bit of respect for him by then, seeing how he ran out front with it. So one evening, a Tuesday maybe-? INT. HART HOME - NIGHT (CHYRON- typed: ‘1990’) MARTIN HART, 36, in better shape and with darker hair, answers his front door. It opens onto RUSTIN COHLE, 31, smaller, handsome but hard-worn, his shirt and suit disheveled. Bleary-eyed and frightened, he stands on the porch with a cheap BOUQUET in hand, as the 2010 Hart spea

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Poor bastard looked like he was on his way to a firing squad. Then I see it- His dark hair mussed, Rust shakily holds out the bouquet. CLOSE ON his face- wet, red eyes, red nose-

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s blind drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bring him in, Marty! Let’s get a look at him! PULL BACK onto the house and see that it is the modest, w maintained home of a middle-class family with small child Hart and Cohle look back and forth at one another, Cohle’ look apologetic and helpless, both understanding that he’ no shape to have dinner with Hart’s family. Hart puts a h on his shoulder, takes the flowers and leads Cohle in-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Just smile and you’1l be fine. I’11 put coffee on. We’ll get somebody to call up here with an excuse for you to leave. Cohle looks like he might cry, either from gratitude or terror-- Then TWO LITTLE GIRLS come hopping in- AUDREY, 10, and MA 7. They surround the two men, giddy at the new visitor. F moment, these two stern men look absolutely baffled by th little girls jumping at their calves, the wilted flowers hanging between them-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same interrogation room, but the chair is EMPTY. A NE MAN steps into frame, sits down. Recognize RUSTIN COHLE, twenty years older, taking Hart’s place across the table, staring at us. Same wall with a corner of the BULLETIN BO behind him, same piece of a WANTED POSTER-- He hasn’t lost any hair, but it’s streaked with steel gra wild, unkempt and in need of a trim. He’s leaner. In the intervening years he’s shed pounds, and now his cheeks ar sunken. He almost looks emaciated, lupine. He’s unshaven, wearing rumpled clothes. NOTICE covering Cohle’s left inn forearm, a colorful, slightly-faded TATTOO of FLAMES with PAIR OF DICE at their apex-- CHYRON (typed): ‘Arkansas State Police CID / Company D / Statement of Cohle, Rustin Spencer. / Present: Sgt. Thoma Papania, Sgt. Maynard Gilbough / May, 2010’ Cohle clears his throat, his voice gravelly, when he fina speaks it’s as if in answer to a question-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (into camera) Yeah. Of course. ‘The Pine Angel.’ Thank the Democrat-Gazette for that one. Cohle pauses and lights a CIGARETTE. Then suddenly looks between it and the camera, as though he’s being admonishe He deliberates the lit cigarette. Then keeps smoking- COHLE (CONT’D) Don’t be a dick about it... You want to hear this or not? (smokes ) Benton County Sheriff requested assistance with a 419 at the edge of the woods off Highway 20. South of Eureka Springs. This our first real heater. I’d been around about three months at the time. Had just observed Marty, till then. Cohle ashes on the table, staring belligerently -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red clouds and a red sunrise. A heavily wooded VALLEY surrounded with denser FOREST, the OZARKS fencing the hor in dun-colored spikes. Blobs of GRAY SNOW litter the dark soil. A crisp, ruby light--  4. FOLLOWING THREE MEN across this valley: a uniformed SHERI DEPUTY walking point, leading TWO MEN IN TRENCHCOATS and suits, MARTIN HART and RUSTIN COHLE, c.1990. Hart’s hands stuffed in his pockets, and Cohle carries a CRIME SCENE K and a LEGAL-SIZED PORTFOLIO-- We watch the deputy leading them toward deeper woods. NOT all the birds roosting outside the forest, and 2010 Cohle speaks in V.O.--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Last gasp of winter. It was about seven a.m., March 3, 1990. My daughter's birthday, I remember. Walking, Rustin sees a BLACK SNAKE winding through the gr away from the direction they’re traveling-- ANGLE AHEAD- where the TREE LINE breaks. SHERIFF'S DEPUTI stand a couple dozen yards from a DARK SHAPE hunched at t base of a LARGE PINE TREE. The men talk between themselve their backs turned away from the shape, breath visible in crisp air--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without saying anything, the deputy leads Hart and Cohle the dark, slumped shape. The deputy tries not to look at but can’t help himself-- ON HART and COHLE’S FACES as the deputy steps aside. Hart looks vaguely horrified. Cohle’s face simply tenses and h eyes sharpen. Behind them, birds shriek from the trees-- Cohle moves past Hart to get closer-- ANGLE ON BODY- (depicted as mercifully as possible) -A wh FEMALE, naked, posed kneeling over a LARGE TREE ROOT, her HANDS folded as if in prayer. Head down, a CROWN of ROOTS THORNS is set on her scalp. A PAIR OF LARGE, DARK WINGS h been attached to her back. The WINGS drape over her ribs, their feather-tips sunken into a small patch of dirty sno Cohle puts on a pair of latex gloves and looks from the b to the TREES around it- NOTICE a PENTAGRAM freshly carved into the pine tree beside the body--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Holy God. Cohle crouches to examine the WINGS. ANGLE ON his hands shifting the feathers.  5. NOTICE the wings are bonded at their axillars with some k of industrial adhesive which has scoured the flesh around them with CHEMICAL BURNS. Cohle gently grasps her head an lifts her FACE- Her face is intact, her eyes gray and dull. It’s not an unattractive face, but white, and something subtle in it- parting of the lips -almost suggests a rapture--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (to deputies) You guys touch anything? One of the uniformed men steps out. SHERIFF TATE, 49, sof and booze-reddened-

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: They know all about crime scenes. You think anybody wants to touch this?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Who found her?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: Hospital chopper on its way to St. Jude's spotted her. Phoned us.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (stands)

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: County’s on his way. Wade Davis. Good man. Cohle looks back at the body, the crown, the wings-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Call state’s. Tell them to send Gordon DiCillo. Tate flares his nostrils, shares a pissed-off glance with deputies. Marty sighs- this rude android for a partner-- Again crouching, Cohle examines the body. FOLLOW his hand which move gently in feathery touches and grips, disturbi as little as possible, while his V.O. speaks-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It was pretty fresh. Animals hadn't been at it. She still had her eyes.  He moves his hands down her body, noting bruises-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lividity at her shoulders, thighs and anterior torso. She was on her stomach a while before he moved her here. ANGLE ON a BLACK MINI-SKIRT hanging above the body on branches, the skirt cut down the middle and spread open l a bat’s wings--

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: You ever seen anything like this?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: No. Eleven years CID.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: Satanic. That’s the word for it. They had a 20/20 on it last year. The SUN has risen higher, and now a SUNBEAM has come down lighting the tableau as if by spotlight. ALL the men noti Cohle looks up, and sees that the killer positioned the b directly beneath a break in the trees, so that sun would purposefully light her figure-

dialogues.speaker: TATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She looks like some kind of religious statue. Cohle looks at her in the sunbeam with new eyes, halted a seeing things differently-

dialogues.speaker: I.D.
dialogues.text: Tate shakes his head. Cohle looks toward the shadows of t Ozarks, the low valley between them a desolate flatness. turns to Hart- a glance gives Cohle permission to take le COHLE (CONT’D) (to Sheriff's) We need more men for a grid search. We'll get troopers out here, but we could use more deputies. I need you guys to set up a perimeter- He points back through the fields, at the far convergence rural highways-  COHLE (CONT’D) -wide as possible on those three roads. One of you post up. Take license plates of anything that passes, too. The deputies just stare at Cohle until he eyes Sheriff Ta Sheriff Tate nods to his men, and they disperse to take positions. Hart pulls out a LARGE RADIO from his trenchco

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: A23. We need trooper assist on that 419. All you can spare for canvass.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: Roger, A23. When he’s done, he puts on latex gloves and crouches besi Cohle, who's already kneeling beside the body. Notice Coh doesn’t care about his pant knees as he writes on that bi LEGAL PAD he’s brought-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (writing) Ligature marks at wrists and ankles. Hemorrhaging around the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 2010 frame, and 56-year old Martin Hart-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (into camera) That's why they called him ‘The Banker’. Most of us, you know, used a little notepad you’d have ina pocket. Rust carried this big portfolio. Wrote down everything. And his first couple months, he had to do a lot of canvassing. So it looked funny. Him going door to door with that big ledger, like the census taker. Thus, The Banker. Not so bad, far as nick-names go. As Martin speaks toward the camera, there is a withheld affection in his remembrance. Clearly, he has a complexit feelings about Rustin Cohle, but ‘respect’ is part of tha HART (CONT’D) I mean, I’d seen the different types. We all fit categories. The bully. The charmer. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HART (CONT’D) The father-figure. The man possessed by ungovernable rage. The eyes. The brain... And any of those types can be a good detective. And any of those types can be an incompetent shitheel. It’s how they manage the burden of authority, yeah? He thinks a moment, perhaps listens to a comment from his interviewer-- HART (CONT’D) It’s like a father’s authority. A father’s burden. It’s too much for some people... Same thing I look for when I hire guys for the agency now. You want a certain toughness. But the kind that doesn’t veer toward callous. Because that’s a dangerous road. Aggression is necessary. It is. So’s compassion, a sense of fairness-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRIME SCENE- Cohle and Hart continue examining the body, Cohle taking furious notes. We cannot hear what they say, only Hart’s 2010 testimony--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You want them to be thorough. To have good eyes, ask the right questions. To have steady habits. ON Cohle’s face as he studies the body, takes notes--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A smart guy who’s steady is hard to find. I mean, I admit, I wasn’t the most brilliant case man the division ever saw. I got lucky a few times. I was alright. Better than some. But I knew how to talk to people. And I was steady. Cohle writes furiously, scans the environment around the

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rust was smart.  EXT. ‘RAINBOW APARTMENTS’, NORTHWEST ARKANSAS - DAY A seedy BRICK line of APARTMENTS the size of motel rooms, the middle of nowhere- fields and desolation around.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Second week we were together I saw where he was living, and I felt for the guy. ANGLE ON an UNMARKED CID CAR, as Cohle and Hart step out, Hart follows his partner to a door-- INT. COHLE’S APARTMENT - DAY Cohle opens the door, and from Hart’s POV, we take in the ROOM. It’s empty except for a couple BOXES. Depressingly bleak and completely unadorned. A MATTRESS on the floor. CRUCIFIX above the mattress. No TV. STACKS OF THICK BOOKS various spots on the floor-

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I thought of some Quasimodo character living in a belfry, like. He had these textbooks stacked on the floor-- ANGLE ON the BOOKS. NOTICE the TITLES: Advanced Crime Sce Analysis. Offender Profiling. Sex Crime Investigation. Advanced Homicide Investigation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart looks at Cohle, a little weirded-out-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’d offer you a seat.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Don’t mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 56-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You know the photos in those books. Not the sort of thing you’d leave lying around, at least if you expected anybody else to ever walk in your place... One of those moments I was glad I’d made a family.  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRIME SCENE- Detectives Cohle and Hart are alone beside t body, having finished their examination. Cohle sits on a and continues writing on his tablet, looking around. Hart stands and talks on the radio. We can’t hear his 1988 voi only the 2010-

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I didn’t really mind he was quiet. Mainly nobody understood what he was doing here. Brought in from Louisiana, and he wasn’t interested in making buddies. Hart puts down the radio, moves to where Cohle sits writi The body nearby, like a dark angel on the periphery of th frame- HART. DiCillo said he’1ll be here in twenty. Cohle doesn’t respond, keeps writing. Hart takes out a ca smokeless tobacco and fills his bottom lip. Then they bot wait, with the silence between them-- ANGLE ON Cohle’s tablet- he’s moved to drawing sketches o the crime scene and body-

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bobby and Steve and the other guys thought he was stuck up, like he thought he’s better than other people. But up close it was more complicated. More like a paranoia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COHLE directs one section of the grid search, and MARTY another-- ON COHLE as he gives orders--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We didn’t know what he’d been doing. Before CID... I didn’t know about all that undercover work until later. A tinge of sympathy is evident in Hart’s voice--  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rustin Cohle, age 51, disheveled, smoking. Somebody broug him an old coffee MUG to use as an ashtray- He pauses,

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. Devil’s in the details, yeah? I wrote everything I could. Try to capture the moment, its essence. Because you never know what the thing’s going to be, do you? The essential, unlikely clue. Thing that, way down the line, maybe months or years later, makes you say, ‘Ah.’ Breaks the case wide. remembering, smokes-- COHLE (CONT’D) So we're sitting there waiting on Dicillo. This scene. I mean, we'd encountered a full-fledged meta- psychotic. I had to explain to Marty what that was-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRIME SCENE: In the distance we can see DEPUTIES spreadin out across the fields. The detectives are still the only near the body. Cohle gestures to it as he speaks to Hart, portfolio laid down-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: This is going to happen again.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What do you think you know?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: This is fantasy enactment. There’s fetishization, something like... iconography.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Satanist shit.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No. But it’s a religious vision. Her body is a paraphilic lovemap.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: A what?  12. Cohle’s eyes trawl over the body--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: An attachment of physical lust to fantasies and practices forbidden by society.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You learn that in your books?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I did. You see how short that skirt was? Decent odds she’s a prost. Maybe a hitchhiker. But the guy’s been thinking about this a long time.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Just don’t want us jumping to any conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I bet we get ID off her prints. Hart, as senior detective, probes Cohle to test his judgm

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Missing persons, obviously. We need to look into any reports of unrelated sexual events, like flashing or fetish burglaries. Check all prior arrests going back the last several years for the northwest counties. Any B&E with a fetish component. Sexual offenders paroled to the state. Hart is impressed by the rookie detective’s assessment. COHLE (CONT’D) These things don’t occur in a vacuum. Hart nods, and Cohle returns to sitting on his log, watch the body. Hart watches him-- Silence for several beats- this dark assemblage flirts wi absurdity- the two suited men sitting near that horrible corpse, being quiet like schoolboys or nervous suitors-- Hart seems perturbed, finally speaks-  13.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: This is a stupid time to mention it. But you have to come over to the house for dinner. I can’t put Maggie off any more, and it’s shitty and rude for you not to. Cohle thinks--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Alright. Cohle looks slightly on edge now, grips his portfolio on lap, stares at the girl. STAY ON Cohle’s face, a dull dre in it, his eyes looking trapped as he sits with Hart--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I get this stone in my gut, see, because I think about Marty’s wife and his two girls, sitting down to dinner with this family, and I’m thinking about Sofia, my daughter, and how it’s her birthday. And how she’s been gone almost five years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older, haunted, Cohle continues his story--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: And I know right then that I’m going to have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRIME SCENE: Later. M.E. GORDON DICILLO has arrived, mid- 40s/50s. He squats by the BODY while an ASSISTANT takes photos under his direction-- In the FIELDS beyond, NOTICE STATE PATROLMEN and SHERIFF’ DEPUTIES walking a slow grid formation through the fields while a few other DEPUTIES hold off a PRESS VAN on the co road. COHLE and HART stand near DiCillo, Cohle almost loo over his shoulder-- ANGLE ON PRUNING SHEARS- DiCillo uses them to cut the WIN at their base with a wet, crunching sound--

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Bagging these separate.  14.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: See if you can find out what type of bird those belong to.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Looks like maybe a turkey vulture. A TROOPER approaches the detectives-

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER
dialogues.text: Sir? We got drag marks-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON slight STREAKS OF BLOOD on the HIGH GRASS, almos imperceptible, as is the wave of mashed-down GRASS leadin between the forest and the road-- Cohle studies them, looks to the road--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: There's going to be some tire tracks on the shoulder of the road there. Can you make tread casts?

dialogues.speaker: TROOPER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Alright. Get casts. Check the opposite shoulder. Cast anything over there, too. I got mold kits in my bag at the scene, if you need them. The trooper nods, hustles off, and Cohle looks at the dra trail, the dark trees and cold, bright sky. He sees SHERI TATE talking to NEWS REPORTERS by TWO NEWS VANS on the ro Cohle’s face scowls--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle whistles with two fingers, waves the sheriff over. sheriff takes his time--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: We need as much of this bend sealed off as possible. Tell the journalists they’re violating the scene.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: They're in the road.  15.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Get them out. You realize what we just caught here?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: Realize it’s my jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It was. But then you called us. I don’t know how they got here so quick, ‘less you called em, feeling left out. But get those jackasses gone. They’re parked on evidence. Tate’s face goes red. A staring contest, and he sees bad things in Cohle’s. The sheriff returns to the reporters-

dialogues.speaker: I./EXT. CID CAR / ARKANSAS HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: HOURS LATER. Toward evening, Cohle and Hart drive in thei UNMARKED CID SEDAN, Hart behind the wheel. They pass VACA

dialogues.speaker: PRAIRIE, ROLLING HILLS, ISOLATED FARMHOUSES--
dialogues.text: Cohle goes through a stack of CANVASS REPORTS and FIELD STATEMENT FORMS on his lap, all filled with Cohle’s meticulous script-- the day’s work--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (re field reports) That’s six hours wasted.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Just that there’s not much around here.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: These people out here. Like they got no idea the outside world exists. They might as well live on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You called her in to Missing Persons?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. First thing. See what DiCillo says, wait for I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I want to start a board. Cohle nods. Silence awhile, and Hart glances to him-  16. HART (CONT’D) Ask you something. That pentagram up there and stuff... You’re Christian, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What? Not on your life. This confuses Hart--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Saw that crucifix in your apartment...

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Oh. That’s more like meditation. Hart is knee-jerk offended at Cohle’s nonchalance about T Son of Man--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I like to contemplate Christ’s life. As an existential statement. The idea of allowing your own crucifixion.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: But you don’t believe He’s the Lord and Savior?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (appalled) What do you believe? Cohle glances at Hart with a tired expression, doesn’t answer. It’s clear he doesn’t want to, but Hart keeps loo at him in expectation--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You don’t want to know.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Three months. I get nothing out of you. And today? After what we're into now? Do me the simple courtesy of answering the question. I’m not trying to convert you.  17. Cohle sighs--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: .-.-In philosophical terms, I’m what’s called a pessimist.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ‘In philosophical terms,’ what’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Means I’m bad at parties. Hart scowls at Cohle, prodding him on. Cohle continues, reluctant- COHLE (CONT’D) I think that human consciousness is a tragic evolutionary misstep. I think that nature fabricated an aspect of nature that’s forever separated from it. A creature that by natural law should not exist. Outside, the car passes a cheap, OLD BILLBOARD with a WOM PORTRAIT on it and the legend ‘10/11/80: DO YOU KNOW WHO KILLED ME? CALL 800-976-5236 REWARD’ -- COHLE (CONT’D) ...I think we are things that labor under the illusion of having a ‘self’, each of us programmed with total assurance that we’re each a somebody. But everybody’s nobody. Cohle gets on a roll now-- COHLE (CONT’D) See, we fabricate meaning in order to deny what we are, so that we can keep on going. Family, god, country, art- these are the materials of our fabrications. We’re uncanny puppets on a lonely planet, in cold space, living and replicating and sending unborn generations into suffering and death because that’s our programming. Hart’s eyes have gone wide with disbelief and frustration

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.  18.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No thanks. And Cohle’s a little enervated, as if, you asked for it-- COHLE (CONT’D) What I think? The only honorable thing for our species to do is deny our programming, stop reproducing and march hand-in-hand into extinction. A beat where Cohle seems almost wistful-- COHLE (CONT’D) A last sunset. Cosmic midnight. Hart’s deeply offended, angry-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So what's the point of life, huh?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: There is no point. Nowhere to go, no one to see, nothing to do, nothing to be.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (enraged) Jesus Christ, Jesus Christ. You bleeding asshole. Most you've said in three months and it’s gotta be- what’s the matter with -Why’re you on the job, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: The only real answer is that it’s obviously my programming. Just like it’s yours. He looks out the window as he speaks, almost to himself-- COHLE (CONT’D) The reason I tell myself? I’ma human being. I speak for the dead. I bear witness. It keeps me part of things. But mostly I lack the courage for suicide... Look, if you want, I could lend you some Schopenhauer. Start there.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop talking. Shit. Shit.  19. Back to silence. As Hart grinds his teeth, Cohle stares o the windows at the ISOLATED FIELDS and RAMSHACKLE HOMES, ELECTRICAL LINES against the DESOLATE VALLEY, BROKEN FENC several tense beats--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I get poor vibrations from this place. You can feel the psycho- field in the air. Like aluminum on your teeth. Hart doesn’t reply, drives on, disturbed, hoping Cohle wo talk anymore-- COHLE (CONT’D) Should I bring anything, for dinner? Horrified to be reminded of the dinner invitation, Hart r composes himself--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Bottle of wine, be nice. I guess.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I don’t really drink. This a final straw of disappointment for Hart--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Of course you don’t, Rust... And listen, at my house? Don’t mention any of that shit you just said to me. You asshole... ‘Extinction.’

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Of course not, Marty. I’m not some maniac. Fuck’s sake. They drive in silence the rest of the way, as Hart’s 2010 vV.O. resumes and the CAR passes down the road, into the hills-

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I mean, most of us are pretty hard right, you know? Christians. Good Republicans. We had pictures of Reagan, Bush and Nixon in the CID squad room. And at this point, no lie-- The CAR shrinks into the dark FOOTHILLS that bound the country road, vanishing into a red darkness--  20.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -I just really, really don’t like the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING the state police headquarters in Fort Smith. four-story administrative building with FLAGS out front, of PATROL and UNMARKED CARS, all late-80s TAURUSES. Hart Cohle’s pulls into the lot as the afternoon reddens towar sunset--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CID is located on the third floor, and Cohle and Hart ent The division is a large, open floor with CUBICLES, TYPEWRITERS, a RECEPTIONIST, and a FEW PLAINCLOTHES DETECTIVES at their desks, using the phones. A FLAG, slog posters, no computers. The receptionist flags Cohle-

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Lieutenant wants you both. Soon as you got back, he told me. Cohle glances at Hart, who shrugs, walks away from him. H is quickly mobbed by the DETECTIVES in the room, all of w want to know about the red-ball he and Cohle have caught- Snatches of their conversation: ‘Said she had wings?’ ‘-t Heavy Metal music-’ ‘You need extra hands?’ ‘A 20/20 spec Etc. INT. LT. QUESADA’S OFFICE, CID - LATE AFTERNOON A boss's OFFICE. Cohle and Hart are sitting in two chairs that face the DESK and, behind it, LT. KEN QUESADA, 3rd S Homicide Commander, Company D, late 40s, chubby, wears a Knights of Columbus RING he likes to rub--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Mid-twenties to late-forties. Looks like strangulation. She had- I mean, you never even heard of anything like this--

dialogues.speaker: RUST
dialogues.text: She had wings attached to her back.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: What, like a costume?

dialogues.speaker: RUST
dialogues.text: Like a real bird’s wings. Big wings, soldered onto her skin.  21.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: RUST
dialogues.text: This is the real thing, Loo. This is way out there.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: That explains why the AP woman asked me about birds. And Satan worship. Godamnit. I had to yell in the sheriff's ear how it’s not a good idea to spout hysterical bullshit to local news. I chewed him up, but I might have to do a press conference tomorrow. Right now, keep it close. Get with me on DiCillo’s report. I’m first to know when you got an ID.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’s going to get a board going.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: You got anything for it? Hart shakes his head. QUESADA (CONT’D) Do it anyway. Incident room’s yours. Lead a briefing tomorrow. Tate wanted to liaise a couple men to us. We might need them, I guess. Scene gonna stay secured?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What good it’1l do. Supposed to snow tonight. A KNOCK on the office window: a SUIT stands there, and Quesada nods to him. Cohle and Hart rise, but--

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: Rust- stay here a minute, huh? Cohle and Hart share a glance as Hart exits, and the SUIT enters. This is Assistant State Attorney LEN SALTER, 40, carries a briefcase and closes the door behind him. Sits in Hart's vacant chair-- Cohle looks back and forth at the two men, who study him openly. As they speak, they are each obviously probing an gauging his reactions--  22. QUESADA (CONT’D) Rustin Cohle. Detective. Eight years with Baton Rouge PD. Four of those with the State Police Intra- agency Task Force... Front lines in the war on drugs.

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: Hard chargers. Took down some major busts. They called you ‘Crash’, right?

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: I heard that, too. ‘Crash’ Cohle.

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: They call you that because you bust things up?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It was a joke with the ITTF. Short for Crash Test Dummy.

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: Hear now they call you ‘The Banker.’ A beat as the two bosses examine Cohle, whose eyes have g hard, flinty-- SALTER (CONT’D) Your op details are redacted. Four years of duty sealed on the Louisiana AG’s orders or classified with DEA. No details. Quesada watches Cohle’s reaction, twists his KofC ring. C becomes indignant--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You realize what we just caught out there?

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: Rust. It’s a few minutes. Cohle twitches at Quesada’s statement, as though the man’ never used his first name before--

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: Few minutes won’t make a difference... How’s it working out for you here, detective? In CID?  23. Cohle shrugs, doesn’t answer. Eye-locked to Salter--

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: Rust. Do something. See if you can guess why the ASA wanted to meet you. Why are we talking? Cohle looks between the two men, studying their expressio

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: In general I’m not trusted, because I moved in under the aegis of former Superintendent Willey, and at the behest of the DEA. Maybe you got word about Northshore. I don’t know. Half the guys think I haven't earned the shield- which is bullshit, by the way. Check my record with robbery. A beat, as the two bosses are impressed by the precision his analysis. Rust seems vaguely angered-- COHLE (CONT’D) Beyond that, the department’s concerned that I may have been inserted as part of an outside investigation. Into what, who knows? But given that the ASA is here, State Attorney Laughlin could be worried about something. So, if Willey’s out, and at three months I’m still here, it’s time to ask your questions.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: See there, Len? I told you.

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: Alright, then, detective. Given your considerable ability to ascertain a situation, let’s be frank. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I want to work murders. That’s it. I had to get out of Louisiana. Special Agent Willis Bokum owed me a favor. More than one. I asked for something like this. This is what he offered.  24.

dialogues.speaker: QUESADA
dialogues.text: Arkansas State Police, though? Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I passed my forensics lab. Aced Practical Homicide Investigation.

dialogues.speaker: SALTER
dialogues.text: .--Is this convincing, Ken?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Convincing for what? Is the idea that I’m secretly running a DEA op? Quesada and Salter look between one another, then back to Cohle. COHLE (CONT’D) For fuck’s-- I have no connections with any outside agency. My transfer was a favor owed. That’s it. They continue to study him, silent, and Cohle realizes th other question they’ve been sitting on- COHLE (CONT’D) SA Laughlin’s running for governor, rumor has it. Your big question is, am I able to provide any kind of information about potential or ongoing fed investigations. Can I keep in the loop, make sure state gets its credit if the feds pull down any winners. A bump around election season... You're asking me about leverage. Quesada and Salter look to one another. Grins. COHLE (CONT’D) I want to work murders. That’s all I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rustin Cohle, 51, facing the camera, smoking yet another cigarette. As if in answer to a question-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Northshore? Psychiatric hospital in Slidell. I spent four months there in ‘88.  25. Cohle smokes a few beats, lets his interviewers digest th knowledge--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle exits Quesada’s office, frustrated, on edge. He loo around at the squad room. Besides Hart, there are four ot detectives there- DEMMA, LUTZ, GERACI and HAYS -all white late-30s/40s. The other detectives eyeball Cohle with no

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I get out Quesada’s office, Marty’s got a board going, and he’s already typing our DL. And like I said before- I’m feeling a lot of stuff hit me at once. My daughter's birthday. This murder. I'ma stranger to myself, man. And I want to drink... Figured to work the case. Keep me out the house while we waited on DiCillo’s report or an I.D. to come in. ANGLE ON Hart typing up the partners’ DAILY LOG. Cohle notices the dry-erase BOARD up at the head of the room, w headings that read: CANVASS REPORTS / TIMELINE / BACKGROU All blank underneath. Cohle walks swiftly to Hart’s desk- COHLE (CONT’D) Hey, you mind if I skate? I’m going to get some names from Vice, local prost hang-outs. Ask around about our DB.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You want me to come?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Nah. It’s just something to do. Go be with your family. Hart nods, without warmth, goes back to typing. Cohle wal out the squad room like he’s making a jail break--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle, 51, speaking into camera. His mood has become less belligerent, more open, as if in recounting these memorie he’s discovered a kind of release through the telling-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: At the time, I kind of struggled with my nights... I mean, I didn’t sleep. Ever.  26. Cohle stares at the camera, and by his eyes we believe th claim-- I./EXT. COHLE’S TRUCK, ROADS - NIGHT Rustin Cohle drives his mid-80s FORD RANGER, north on HWY toward Fayetteville, Springdale and Rogers. As he drives, smokes-- He opens a bottle of ROBITUSSIN and guzzles the whole thi grimaces, tosses the bottle out the window. His eyes are furious-- AUDIO PRELAP: SOUND of BRAKES SQUEALING, TIRES SPINNING--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASHBACK: Rustin Cohle, 26, runs into the street, a look pure terror on his face, a toddler's THREE-WHEELER bent a twisted at the edge of the frame. Behind him, his WIFE dr to her knees, screaming. Blood on the road around the bik

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I./EXT. COHLE’S TRUCK, ROADS - NIGHT Cohle driving, smoking. A 2010 V.0.-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: State Vice gave me some addresses to look at. So far nobody talked to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING-- partially obscured by the interstate, blac country darkness around it, the TRUCK STOP’S LIGHTS spark out the night, its lot full of BIG RIGS, a well-lit depression of heavy machinery. It could be a mining outpo on a distant asteroid-- Cohle’s truck pulls in-- NOTICE a SMALL BAR called Jenny O's adjacent to the truck stop, in the same oasis. Cohle parks, watches the place. finds George Strait on the radio, “He Stopped Loving Her Today” -- Cohle watches a WOMAN climb out the CAB of a PARKED TRUCK wiping her mouth. He sees ANOTHER WOMAN climb from ANOTHE TRUCK, and then watches both women walk into Jenny O'’s- NOTICE, with Cohle, a small PLAYGROUND AREA off to the si of the truck stop, its slides and swings looking lonely i the darkness--  27. SFX: A child’s delighted LAUGHTER, an aural hallucination Cohle wipes tears out his eyes, shuts off the truck and starts walking toward Jenny 0O’s--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart (36) enters a darkened house, obviously late night. He shuffles to the kitchen, pours a tall glass of Jamesons, and a sloppiness in his gestures suggests this not his first drink of the night-- He walks to the hallway, sipping his drink, still wearing trenchcoat, which perhaps overtly suggests his role as investigator. He pauses in the DOORWAY of his GIRLS’ ROOM Martin’s POV, watching his two girls sleep in the blue darkness. On his face, sipping his drink, something unset in his gaze, perhaps connected to the woman’s body found day, perhaps connected to Rust’s philosophies--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart has a fresh drink and is looking through the slim contents of a bookcase. He picks out the one he was looki for ‘National Audubon Society Field Guide to the Southeas States’ -- He takes the drink and book to an armchair, starts readin under lamp light. A lonely image, a man drinking alone in dark, studying the detritus of murder-- INT. JENNY O’S TAVERN, ARKANSAS - LATE NIGHT A smoky, cramped BAR. TRUCKERS inside, hard-worn men watc basketball on the television, scraps of neon, tinsel, Razorbacks football posters. NOTICE the TWO WOMEN Cohle s exiting big rigs, now seated together at a narrow table i back corner. One or two other WOMEN, similarly hard-worn, scattered inside-- ANGLE ON Cohle, approaching the back corner table. He smi and addresses the women. One thin and blonde, the other p shaped, a brunette--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: (cop alert) Oh, come on, man-  28.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’s hoping I could ask y’all a few questions. I got the next round.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: You making trouble? Sir?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No ma’am. I’m just looking for info about a woman, might be you know her.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNETTE
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Hold on. The blonde (Lucy- 20s), upends her beer, draining it. She slides the empty pint glass to Cohle, includes the brunet (Annette) in her gesture--

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Two Long Island Teas, please. INT. JENNY O’S TAVERN, ARKANSAS - LATE NIGHT ANGLE ON Cohle returning to the table with two large drin

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: My name’s Rust, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: I’m Annette. She’s Lucy. Lucy shoots her daggers for saying names. Cohle sits down they each start drinking--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Either of you maybe know a woman, could be about your ages, might work around the same places. About five’ five, shortish hair, dyed blonde, thin.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What kind of tits she have?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Just about medium, I guess. Maybe a little small.  29.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: Jeez. I don’t know. I mean, I know a couple girls like that.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Any of them missing? Like any you haven’t seen around lately?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What you want them for? You busting somebody?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I would never bust a person for prostitution. Or drugs. At the word ‘drugs’, Lucy’s eyes dart to her purse, and C clocks the tell-- COHLE (CONT’D) I’m murder police.

dialogues.speaker: ANNETTE
dialogues.text: Somebody got killed.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: There’s a girl named Liza, and one calls herself Precious. But I seen Precious yesterday at McDonald’s.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What about Liza?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She's here. Lucy points across the bar to a thin, haggard BLONDE chat up a TRUCKER-- LUCY (CONT’D) What happened, this girl you’re looking for? Rust studies the TRUCKERS along the bar, their faces, cle pondering the possibility of the killer being a trucker-- He turns back to the women, stands, and hands them each a business card--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: That’s me. Detective Sergeant. You help me out of this, maybe I can help you some time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m looking for a girl by that description, shoulda been missing a couple days, at least. He hands Annette a ten-dollar bill-- COHLE (CONT’D) Could you grab a couple more drinks, Annette? She glances to Lucy, who nods, then walks to the bar. Coh leans toward Lucy, hushed-- COHLE (CONT’D) You get pills pretty easy? Lucy's face twists in panic-- COHLE (CONT’D) Relax. I want some.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Speed?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No. Quaalude. Anything-barbital.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Uppers are easier to get. Last longer, too.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It’s not like that.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What’s it like?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep. ON Lucy’s face, confused--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning, pale pink and blue light flushes t windows. Martin Hart sleeps in T-shirt and work slacks on recliner, the Audubon Guide open on his chest, an empty G turned over on the carpet beside the chair-- ANGLE ON Maggie Hart, 35, entering the living room from hallway, still wearing Martin’s old FOOTBALL JERSEY, whic she sleeps in. She goes to the KITCHEN NOOK, starts coffe As she waits for it to brew, she watches her husband, a sadness in her eyes--  31. She moves to him. Nudges him awake--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey, Baretta. Hart’s eyes flutter, and he shoots up in the chair, as if the middle of a nightmare-- MAGGIE (CONT’D) Hey. Hey. Why’re you out here?.. Why didn’t you come to bed? He’s still groggy, coming out of sleep, and doesn’t pick on her dejection--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: .--Didn’t- I couldn’t sleep. Caught a bad one yesterday. (re Audubon Guide) I fell asleep doing some research.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: On birds? Her eyes search for his. He simply nods-- MAGGIE (CONT’D) Girls’1ll be up soon. Missed you the last couple days.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Shit. I gotta shower. I’m debriefing today. He jumps out the chair, gives Maggie a peck on the cheek walks down the hallway-- On Maggie, trying not to be hurt, trying to understand by that it’s not personal, that her husband’s job changes people. She moves back to the kitchen and begins preparin breakfast--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING Hart as he enters CID, nods to the RECEPTIONIST THREE OTHER DETECTIVES milling around the coffee pot. The nod hellos. Hart reaches his cubicle and sees that COHLE, across from him, has already arrived, bags under his eyes

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: R&I came back early this morning. Dora Kelly Lange, 28. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: COHLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Priors for shoplifting and, can you believe it, solicitation.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Little early for your sort of self- satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’ve never been satisfied with myself, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I got something too. He pulls the Audubon Guide from his jacket- HART (CONT’D) I think the wings were Cathartes aura. That’s a turkey vulture, son.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: A big one. He hands Lange’s FILE to Hart, who begins perusing it- COHLE (CONT’D) Her address lists as Fayetteville, but landlord says she hasn't lived there in over a year. Has an ex, Charlie Lange, doing eight in Pine Bluff for burglary and possession. Mother outside of Rogers. Line’s disconnected. DMV license expired.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: DiCillo called. Immediately grabs Hart’s attention--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside an AUTOPSY ROOM, standard-issue, TILED WALLS and FLOORS, STEEL TABLES, SURGICAL EQUIPMENT, SINKS, etc. Coh and Hart stand with GORDON DICILLO, all facing TWO TABLES one table lies the woman’s BODY, clean and intact except the Y-INCISION. On the other table sit the WINGS, positio as they were on her back, and the CROWN of roots. DiCillo reads from his report, inside a MANILA FOLDER thick with papers--  33.

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: R&I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Her name’s Dora Lange. She’s 28. DiCillo looks through his papers. As he reads, NOTICE the separate reactions of each detective. Hart more visibly w his emotions, not looking at the body, his face flexing w rage as he listens. Cohle stares at the body, following a with DiCillo’s descriptions, his face cold, intense--

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Weather in the forest treated us pretty well. Time of death between one and two a.m., March 3rd, 1988. COD was manual strangulation. Fingernail marks and hemorrhaging around the throat, fractured hyoid and presence of thyroid cartilage. Petechial hemorrhaging... She was washed clean, too. Not a print. Ligature marks around her wrists and ankles, bound with quarter-inch rope. Judging by the marks, she was tied up for maybe ten to twenty hours... Cohle moves closer to the table, begins slowly walking ar it, eyes devouring- DICILLO (CONT’D) Evidence of vaginal and anal intercourse. Appears consensual. Traces of spermicidal lubricant. He used a condom.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Surprising.

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I figured him for impotent.

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: .--Possible object insertion, as well. Each man has something like a personal moment of silence. This entire scene is intense, sad and emblematic of the detective’s role in the life of his species--  34. DICILLO (CONT’D) She was bound upright.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Stomach contents?

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Hadn’t eaten in a day, maybe more. Toxicology’s positive for cocaine, Lysergic acid and Diazepam.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Valium?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: And LSD.

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Might be enough to put even you down a rabbit hole, Detective Cohle. DiCillo hinting that he’s heard stories--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Piss in my ear a little more, Gordon. Let’s kill some more time.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: How much LSD?

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: Maybe a couple-thousand micrograms. You know how much that is?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Enough to see dancing bears for a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: It’s a lot.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: And if she didn’t know she’d taken it, it’d be like hell’s carnival.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So she was drugged, bound. Then strangled. And left out there like that. Posed.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What about the wings?  35.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Turkey vulture?

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: That’s right. Three or four years old. An adult male. The wings were taxidermied, held together with wire, rubber cement, clear epoxy spray. They were removed with a sharp, straight blade, maybe a box cutter. Held on to her with thermoplastic adhesive. Industrial hot-glue. A lot of it. Burned through the top layers of her skin.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: She alive for that? All three men look at one another--

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: I really can’t say... Her fingernails are cracked, but the only blood is hers. Found fiberboard splinters in the scrapings you took.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Like she tried to scratch through a door. Tripping. Locked up somewhere. Cohle looks at her FACE-- not exactly pretty, but once cu somehow malnourished, obviously poor-- Hart moves to the table with the WINGS and CROWN

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: The crown. For want of a better word. Switchgrass, ivy, and rose stems. Tied together with common twine. No prints. The men stand there, almost breathless after this catalog

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Anything else? DiCillo shakes his head--

dialogues.speaker: DICILLO
dialogues.text: I’ve been an M.E. for nineteen years. Not a lot you don’t see in that time.  36. He hands Hart the REPORT, and doesn’t let go of it right away, so that they both grip it, and their eyes meet, as though DiCillo is tasking him to find justice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. CORONER’S OFFICE, FORT SMITH, AR - DAY Cohle and Hart step out the office, both badly needing fr air. The BUILDING is an old brick and limestone cube, and around it are the tatters of an ABANDONED COMMERCIAL NEIGHBORHOOD. They each walk several feet away from the entrance, then stand and, in a mental sense, catch their breath--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: All this trouble. This is real personal.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No. Not personal. The enactment was the thing. Not the victim.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You know this how?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: This isn’t an opportunity killing. It’s a fetish enactment. In a way, it’s almost impersonal-- Cohle and Hart start walking back to their car, passing a small strip of STORES with BROKEN WINDOWS, CARDBOARD patc KUDZU and IVY growing wildly all over everything, HIGH GR breaking through the sidewalks-- COHLE (CONT’D) (xe neighborhood) It’s like walking in somebody's memory of a real town. And the memory’s fading. And it turns out there was really never anything there but jungle. Hart stops walking-- COHLE (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I want you to stop saying shit like that. It’s unprofessional.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You want me to be someone else?  37.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I want you to stop saying odd shit. Like you sense a ‘psycho-field’, or whatever. Or that you’re walking in somebody’s memory.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Well, Marty, given how long it’s taken me to understand and reconcile my own nature, I can’t hardly imagine I’d forgo it on your account. The two men stare at each other, the potential for violen humming in the air, placed there by the horror they just toured. That is, unable to discuss feelings, both men vee toward anger-- Then, as if remembering their actual purpose, they deflat They reach the car and open the doors--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You get any sleep last night?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep. I just dream. They get in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to 2010, Martin Hart addressing us across the table-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: That dinner? What I started to- yeah. That was later... Well, I thought the flowers were funny. I guess he’d read somewhere you should bring flowers when somebody invites you to dinner. He pauses, remembering, almost annoyed-- HART (CONT’D) I told him to bring wine. And him having told me he don’t drink. Showing up in that condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUING the opening dinner scene. Hart and Cohle now s on Hart’s back deck, Hart drinking a beer and Cohle smoke holding a cop of coffee.  38. We can see inside through the doors, into the KITCHEN, wh Hart’s wife MAGGIE and his TWO GIRLS set the table-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What the hell? I invite you over to dinner. Once. You can barely stand up. You don’t drink with me or Demma or Lutz after work. But you gotta get a load on before you visit my family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohle shakes his head, slugs coffee and sucks a cigarette like it contains an antidote, his voice a little slurred-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t like that, Marty. I didn’t mean to... I don’t drink... Because it’s given me problems before. Yeah? Nothing we need to discuss. I didn’t mean to have so many. Hart waits further explanation, still insulted- COHLE (CONT’D) I was checking on a CI. She was late and I ended up hanging around a bar for an hour. I was sitting there and couldn’t really think of a good reason not to have one. Usually I can. Hart looks him over. He slaps Cohle’s shoulder, relieved this show of fallible humanity from Cohle-- HART. Don’t worry about it. Have some more coffee. Try to make ten minutes of conversation. I'll call Chris or somebody and have them call up here for you. Say one of your old cases caught a break.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Forget it. We’ll do it another time. Cohle puts out his cigarette and Hart lets him walk in fi Hart watches him with apprehension-  39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short time later. Dinner with the Hart family, everyone the table now, Cohle still rumpled, drinking coffee and looking at least a little more sober. MACIE and AUDREY pi their food while making faces at one another. Hart cuts h steak quietly, letting MAGGIE carry the conversation-

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I said, ‘Your life’s in this man’s hands? Am I wrong?’ Of course he should meet the family.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You know it’s not that dramatic. (to Rust) Never used my gun.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Rust) Have you? Used your gun? Cohle pauses, looks at the table and the girls who’ve tur their attention to him--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: Have you shot people?!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Macie-

dialogues.speaker: MACIE
dialogues.text: Daddy’s never shot anybody.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: That’s good. You don’t want to have to shoot people.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: But you have, huh? A beat as Cohle considers lying--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Marty says you’re from Louisiana?  40.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Southwest Louisiana. Yeah. But I's working in Texas too, before here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What kind of work?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Narcotics, mostly. I was on robbery squad in Baton Rouge till ‘85. At the word ‘narcotics’, Hart’s eyes jump to Cohle’s arm, where his rolled sleeve depicts the edge of his FLAME AND DICE TATTOO. In the house, the PHONE RINGS--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I'll get it. Keep eating. He rises--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart stands beside he and Maggie’s bed, talking on a PHON that rests on a nightstand--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (into phone) Thanks for calling. He’1l appreciate it... Then I appreciate it. Hart sets the phone on a pillow. FOLLOW as he walks down short hallway, back to the dining area adjoining the kitc He pauses a moment, as he sees Maggie and Cohle talking between one another, with lowered voices-- As he approaches, he can hear Cohle’s hushed voice-

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) --in the street. We didn’t last long after that. Transferred to narco. 24/7. When Hart reaches the table, Cohle stops talking, and Har sees that his eyes are a little wet--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Chris Demma’s on the phone for you. Something about one of your opens. Cohle nods, excuses himself and walks to the back bedroom Hart notices that Maggie seems newly quiet, suddenly sad-  41. HART (CONT’D) What was that? What were you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How he got here. Marty, what do you know about him?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Not much. Could be a good detective. He’s running with the new one. She dabs her eyes with her napkin, emotionally affected b something--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You notice how he looks like he lost his wife, his dog, and his best friend all on the same day? Hart shrugs-- MAGGIE (CONT’D) You ever ask him about that?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Baby, trust me. You do not want to pick this guy’s brain. Cohle re-appears, and they both turn abruptly. HART (CONT’D) (re phone call) You need to go?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Nah. It’s nothing can’t wait. Hart is slightly taken aback. Cohle’s not going through w the escape plan, but instead sits back down to finish his meal--

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You were saying, Rust? About the marriage?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Aw, you know, we can find something nicer to talk about. Marty- I saw your tying table. You fly-fish?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Little bit.  42. Marty doesn’t respond further, bothered, shovels food in mouth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 56--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I resented it. Maybe I didn’t like that he stayed, when he could have left in all politeness. Or I resented that Maggie was getting him to talk so much. Some point of recollection catches him, and he digresses slightly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the dinner table, Hart eats in silence while Cohle and Maggie talk and the girls laugh with one another. The onl dialogue Hart’s 2010 V.0O.--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She did love to talk. Loved sitting around a table, gabbing. Everybody in her family did. I wasn’t much for that. Never had been, but especially when I’m off work... Cohle says something and Maggie laughs--

dialogues.speaker: HART, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One of those consequences of the job, huh? Silence, monotony. These were the friends of my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 56--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So why’m I telling you about dinner? We oughta talk about Dora Lange. Yeah?.. We stay on Martin Hart’s face as it suspiciously studies camera--  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart and Cohle stand in front a room of TEN OTHER DETECTI with LT. QUESADA standing to their right, a large DRY-ERA BOARD between them. Squad debrief-- Quesada holds up a copy of the ARKANSAS DEMOCRAT-GAZETTE. HEADLINE: Angel Murdered in Pines of Benton-- Cohle has tacked on the board several of the M.E.’S PHOTO from the scene. Hart writes the name DORA LANGE across th top of the board--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: She look like an angel to any of you guys? No one answers, but they eye-fuck Cohle enough that he st back--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (re board) This is what we have right now. The detectives listen--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Hart, 56, speaking in response to his interviewer-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Me? I joined in ‘75, when I’s 24. BA in criminal justice from U of Ark. One semester of law school. He looks over his big knuckles, his COLLEGE RING-- HART (CONT’D) Wasn’t for me. Desks. I was always an athlete, see, and I think that’s key to something. Like it has to do with the need to not be stabled. Same sort of thing maybe makes someone right for certain sports. That urge to run out front. Reflecting, he shrugs, not really caring to analyze himse too deeply-- HART (CONT’D) I wanted action. I wanted to be there, at the places behind our lives. I wanted to walk past the yellow tape... And to protect. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HART (CONT’D) Do good. Same stuff that led to me opening up the agency after I took my pension. Why I doubt I’1l ever stop. Almost congratulating himself-- HART (CONT’D) I just need to be out there. Making moves. Digging... It’s what Rust called ‘the narcotic of knowing. A long pause, where it appears Hart is receiving a questi HART (CONT’D) Met Margaret my senior year. She was a freshman. Eighteen and straight off the tree. Small, with freckled skin. A big pile of thick, black hair. Green eyes. Irish. This ass. Tits like softballs. I’1l say it. We should celebrate those memories, if we got em, yeah? His tone drops a little-- HART (CONT’D) Gets difficult to remember her like that, like back then. I thought Audrey or Macie would look like her as they grew, but they look like me. I don’t even have pictures of Maggie from back then... Burned them all one night. Shit- hammered. Wish I hadn’t done that, now. He straightens, dispels the nostalgia and speaks directly HART (CONT’D) Anyway- we were married for twenty- five years. And for the last fourteen I worked with Rust Cohle. I mean, that long a time, a relationship becomes lots of different things. Different incarnations... Rust changed a lot, back and forth. We both did. And yeah, we left it bad. But, you know, I can say this: he was a great detective. Things I saw Rust do-- A beat. Oddly, he grins--  HART (CONT’D) Look. I try not to hold grudges... I believe that kind of thinking can lead to cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long briefing obviously ending, Hart is giving 45. assignments to the DETECTIVES who aren’t otherwise occupi As he says their NAMES, they move out. NOTICE who’s-who a them. While he talks, Cohle hands out flyers with Dora’s MUG SHOT and a list of her known associates--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Lutz and Farvre, get you to do the hooker questioning. Lutz and Farvre groan-- HART (CONT’D) Demma, Geraci, if you guys can talk to old neighbors, the former landlord... Emmett, Will, you guys can free-float, work your CIs, take her flyer around to the truck stops, prost rousts. Visit with the Springfield cops who busted her in ‘87.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (EMMETT)
dialogues.text: Sure you guys got enough to do?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I put some troopers checking northwest crime reports for flashing, fetish burglaries. Anything with a lust component, going back ten years. You want that? Thompson's silent, resentful-

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We're going to start with her ex- husband. Pine Bluff State Pen. We’re handling her mom and ex, but find some KAs. Everybody check back at five, yeah? You get anything, put in on the board. The detectives disperse. Quesada nods approvingly to Hart ignores Cohle, and walks to his office--  46.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (re lieutenant) What was that about? With Quesada, yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Nothing. The State Attorney just thought I had flex. Which I don’t. Come on, let’s hit it. Hart follows Cohle to the EXIT, suspicious and further un of his partner--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unmarked CID CAR travels southeast along I-40, travel through FOOTHILLS, FOREST, LAKES, natural beauty, all fro with the last vestiges of a clingy winter. NOTICE rising above the trees, the ENORMOUS FUSION TOWERS of ARKANSAS NUCLEAR ONE, a nuclear plant in the middle of otherwise picturesque surroundings. The car seems to take forever t pass the structure, it’s so immense--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: So... dinner next week?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ...Yeah. More silence, as the shadow of the NUKE TOWERS passes--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: (re nuke plant) How many of those things you think the Russians got?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I oughta look that up. Hart, tenser, remains silent, and we are reminded that we barely out of the COLD WAR at this point. Cohle stares ou the windows-- The car passes a LITTLE GIRL standing by the side of the road. She waves to the men-- COHLE (CONT’D) You believe in ghosts?  47.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: That’s it. Stop. Just stop. Please. Please don’t talk anymore. Till we get there. Turn on the radio or something. It’s yours. Cohle doesn’t react to this, doesn’t even turn from the window-- HART (CONT’D) Why’d you ask that?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: No reason. Cohle keeps staring out the window as the car accelerates of frame--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING- an imposing, concrete PRISON, its walls fla and forboding, a fortress. FOLLOW the detectives’ CAR as GATES PART for it, and it seems diminished against the HI WALLS and BATTLEMENTS-- ANGLE ON Cohle and Hart exiting the car, looking up at th MAIN PRISON in such a way that it seems impossibly large, they pause, as if standing before their own futures. Then they start walking toward it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VISITING ROOM, GUARD posted by the door. Cohle and Hart at a table, across from which is CHARLIE LANGE, head shav in orange prison jumpsuit, ARYAN TATTOOS curling up beyon his sleeve and neckline. He’s thin, hollow-eyed--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We want to talk about your ex-wife. Dora. Lange is put-off by the topic--

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Man, what she said I done now? Can’t get ‘way from the bitch fer nothing.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You know what she’s up to nowadays? Where’s she living?  48.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Nope. She got the papers pushed through when they locked me in here. Ain't heard from her. Prolly smoking pole for rent. As they talk, the detectives scrutinize Lange’s face for cues or obfuscations. NOTICE the visual echoes of Hart an Cohle’s own interrogations, twenty years later--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: She got any drug habits, you know of?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Had a couple. Last I saw.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: How’d you two meet?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Grew up in the same parts, didn’t we? Mena. Dropped out high school together. Hitched up.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Man, what always happens? Men and women, yeah? You want a wife but only ‘bout half the time.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: I hear you, Charlie. Let me ask you something. If you’re telling us you haven't talked to Dora since the divorce, why do prison phone records show a different story? A gutsy bluff on Cohle’s part, having read something in Lange's bearing, and now he’s unsettled--

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Uh. That’s right. Talked to her a little bit a couple weeks back. I's trying to get her to float me some scratch. My store was empty.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What did she say?  49.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She wasn’t no help. Sounded blotto. Nonsense jabber... Man, y'all axing me a lot of questions. What I get?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: A healthy endorsement to the parole board.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Ain’t worth a snitch jacket.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Who you snitching on?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Appearances, brah.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Give me a break. This is Pine Bluff. It’s a goddamn day camp. Spend some time in Angola. Or Huntsville. I’m surprised they even got aryan nation in here.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Where was she staying, when you called her?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Had a number for her friend, Carla. Carla got her to call me back. Hart takes out a small notepad and pen--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Carla’s full name and phone number. He passes the pad to Lange, who writes awkwardly, slides back--

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Don’t know her full name. Works at the Conoco.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You said Dora was talking nonsense or something?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. Just stupid shit. Didn't even make sense. Pissed me off. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LANGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like, how I’m gonna talk to you, you this in the bag? Right?

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: What did she say. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Uh, shit. Crank talk, like. Talking she'd been saved and she wanted me to be saved. Said some... Slurred. I don’t know. It didn’t make sense. Cohle and Hart glance at one another--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this. You know where her mama lives? She still in Rogers?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You got a phone number?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Miss Bernie don’t use no phone.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Where’s she live, in Rogers?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Sycamore Street. Less she died. Say, look- what'd Dori do? She in trouble? Girl could use a stay in here, ask me.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: In ‘87, she’s busted for soliciting.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Got thrown out. Acquitted.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You pimped for her, Charlie? Charlie is proud when he lies--

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Naw, man.  51.

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: You ran scams together, yeah? What else two heads gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Try this. Is she still tricking, far as you know?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don’t know. Listen. Couple weeks ago’s the first time I talked to her in more’n a year. And she’s gone batshit. All I know... What’s up y’all? What’d she do? Hart and Cohle look at Lange, whose expression says he’s starting to figure out why they’re here-- Lange begins to sink into the realization--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rustin Cohle, 51, looking like he’s ready to leave, in th middle of speaking to his interviewers--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: -Why not? This isn’t official. You all asked to pick my brains. This isn’t evidence. You ever work a room? You ever buy a suspect a cheeseburger and coke? He pauses for an answer, indicates he’s looking between t people-- COHLE (CONT’D) Great. Take five bucks and have somebody go out and grab me a six- pack. Pabst or Lone Star’s fine. Nothing fancy. Another pause as he receives a question-- COHLE (CONT’D) Because it’s Thursday and it’s past noon. Thursday’s one of my off- days. On my off-days I start drinking at noon. He looks very serious, and as though this were a life-and death matter-- JUMP CUT: as though on a badly-spliced video-  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later. Cohle has a SIX-PACK of PABST in fro of him, along with his ash-mug and cigarettes. He pops a and guzzles half of it with relish. Lights a cigarette--

dialogues.speaker: COHLE
dialogues.text: Thank you, boys. Thank you... Now maybe we can get to brass tacks. Cause I know why I’m here. He sits back a little, drags on the cigarette-- COHLE (CONT’D) It’s started again, hasn’t it? The killing. Him. And how can that be possible, when we got the bastard in 2000? He sips the beer, smokes-- COHLE (CONT’D) How indeed, gentlemen. How indeed. CLOSING IN on Cohle’s eyes, haunted, intense, as he drink hits his cigarette, stares into the camera-- BLACK.
